revisions.comment: /* Formal definitions */ Both order embeddings and isometries must be injective.
/* Generalizations */ *On a [[pseudo-Euclidean space]], the term ''isometry'' means a linear bijection preserving magnitude.

kill one example of the isometry group. This article is not about [[isometry group]]s, rather about isometries.

It is the [[symmetry group]] of the space itself. The symmetry group of any subset of the space is a subgroup of the isometry group.

I think that there is nothing to merge
Every combination of these is the combination of just one rotation about an axis, and a translation along the axis (with as special cases pure rotation and pure translation).
/* Examples */ In 1D, the isometries are the translations and the reflections in a point.
/* Generalizations */ Cleaned up muddled definition of ε-isometry

one can think of a piece of a jigsaw puzzle, or a transparency with an image. In 3D the rotations and translations are also simply the possible moves of a rigid object, but the reflections are not; ho
/* Examples */ In 2D, the isometries correspond to the possible physical moves of a rigid flat object from a plane to that same plan, allowing temporarily leaving that plane to flip it over.
added material from [[metric space]] introduction. Perhaps someone can add some more basic applications of isometric mappings.
